description: gpg-agent - Secret key management for GnuPG

global_flags.description: Pinentry  to allow features to divert the passphrase entry to a running Emacs instance.  How this is  exactly  handled  de‐ pends on the version of the used Pinentry.
Allow is the default.
the internal cache of gpg-agent with passphrases.

area  as  required. The  optional value n is a non-negative integer with a suggested size in bytes of each additionally allocated secure memory area. The value is rounded up to the next 32 KiB; usual C  style  pre‐ fixes are allowed.  For an heavy loaded gpg-agent with many con‐ current connection this option avoids sign or decrypt errors due to out of secure memory error returns.
thing  requiring  human interaction.
check new passphrases against pattern in FILE

in  file.   When entering  a new passphrase matching one of these pattern a warn‐ ing will be displayed.  If file does not contain any slashes and does not start with "~/" it is searched in the system configura‐ tion directory (‘/etc/gnupg’).  The default is not  to  use  any pattern  file.   The  second version of this option is only used when creating a new symmetric key to allow the use of  different patterns for such passphrases.

Format  the info output in daemon mode for use with the standard Bourne shell or the C-shell respectively.   The  default  is  to guess  it  based on the environment variable SHELL which is cor‐ rect in almost all cases.
run in daemon mode (background)

debug flags.  All flags are or-ed and flags may be given in C syntax (e.g. 0x0042) or as a  comma  separated  list  of  flag names.   To  get  a  list of all supported flags the single word "help" can be used. This option is only useful for debugging and the behavior may change at any time without notice.
the debug level for investigating problems. level may be a numeric value or a keyword:
option  enables  extra debug information pertaining to the Pinentry.  As of now it is only  useful  when  used  along  with

random  quality level (Libgcrypt’s GCRY_VERY_STRONG_RANDOM) and degrades all re‐ quest  down  to  standard  random  quality.  It is only used for testing and should not be used for any production quality  keys. This option is only effective when given on the command line.
the actual  processing  loop  and print the pid.  This gives time to attach a debugger.

The  default is  600  seconds.   Each time a cache entry is accessed, the en‐ try's timer is reset.  To set an entry's maximum  lifetime,  use max-cache-ttl.  Note that a cached passphrase may not be evicted immediately from memory if no client requests a cache operation. This  is  due to an internal housekeeping function which is only run every few seconds.
sec‐ onds.   The default is 1800 seconds.  Each time a cache entry is accessed, the entry's timer is reset.  To set an entry's maximum lifetime, use max-cache-ttl-ssh.

a  periodic  self-test  to  detect  a  stolen socket.   This  usually means a second instance of gpg-agent has taken over the socket and gpg-agent will then terminate  itself. This  option may be used to disable this self-test for debugging purposes.
The extended key format  is  used  for  years  now  and  has been supported since 2.1.12.  Existing keys in the old format are migrated to the new format as soon as they are touched.
This option has  the  ef‐ fect of disabling the ability to do smartcard operations.  Note, that  enabling  this  option at runtime does not kill an already forked scdaemon.
do not allow the reuse of old passphrases
enable ssh support
user  to bypass them using the ``Take it anyway'' button.
extra socket is created by default, you may use this option to change the name of the socket.  To disable  the  creation  of the socket use ``none'' or ``/dev/null'' for name.
option is only useful for testing; it sets the system time back or forth to epoch which is the number  of  seconds  elapsed since the year 1970.
let PIN-Entry grab keyboard and mouse

the  home  directory  defaults to ‘~/.gnupg’.  It is only recognized when given on the command line.   It  also  overrides any  home  directory  stated  through  the  environment variable ‘GNUPGHOME’ or (on Windows systems) by means of the Registry en‐ try HKCU\Software\GNU\GnuPG:HomeDir.

option  will let gpg-agent bypass the passphrase cache for all signing operation.  Note that there is  also  a  per-session option  to  control  this  behavior but this command line option takes precedence.
window  system's DISPLAY  variable  respectively.   This  is  useful  to lock the pinentry to pop up at the tty or display you started the agent.
ignore requests to change the TTY
The  default is 64.

This is very helpful in see‐ ing what the agent actually does.  Use  ‘socket://’  to  log  to socket.   If  neither  a  log file nor a log file descriptor has been set on a Windows platform, the  Registry  entry  HKCU\Soft‐ ware\GNU\GnuPG:DefaultLogFile,  if  set,  is used to specify the logging output.
After this time a cache entry will be expired even if it has been  ac‐ cessed  recently  or  has  been set using gpg-preset-passphrase. The default is 2 hours (7200 seconds).
After this time a cache entry will be  expired  even if  it has been accessed recently or has been set using gpg-pre‐ set-passphrase.  The default is 2 hours (7200 seconds).
the  user  to  change  the passphrase if n days have passed since the last  change.   With  --enforce-passphrase-constraints set the user may not bypass this check.
the  minimal  length  of a passphrase.  When entering a new passphrase shorter than this value a warning will be  displayed. Defaults to 8.

the minimal number of digits or special characters required in a passphrase.  When entering a new passphrase with less  than this  number  of  digits or special characters a warning will be displayed.  Defaults to 1.
disallow the use of an external password cache
disallow caller to override the pinentry
This makes it harder for users to in‐ advertently accept Root-CA keys.
detach the process from the console.  This is mainly use‐ ful for debugging.
This  option should be used on X-Servers to avoid X-sniffing attacks. Any use of  the  option  --grab overrides an used option --no-grab.  The default is --no-grab.
This implies  the  [op‐ tion --no-allow-mark-trusted].

configuration  from file instead of from the default per- user configuration file.   The  default  configuration  file  is named  ‘gpg-agent.conf’  and  expected in the ‘.gnupg’ directory directly below the home directory of the user.  This  option  is ignored if used in an options file.
option  asks  the Pinentry to enable passphrase formatting when asking the user for a new passphrase  and  masking  of  the passphrase is turned off.
option asks the Pinentry to use char for displaying hidden characters.  char must be one character UTF-8 string.  A  Pinen‐ try may or may not honor this request.
The default is installa‐ tion dependent.  With the default configuration the name of  the default  pinentry is ‘pinentry’; if that file does not exist but a ‘pinentry-basic’ exist the latter is used.
The default value of 0 does not ask the pinentry to timeout,  however  a  Pinentry  may  use its own default timeout value in this case.  A Pinentry may or may not  honor  this  re‐ quest.

is  passed to Pinentry, so that it can touch that file before exiting (it does this only in curses mode).  This  option changes  the  file  passed to Pinentry to filename.  The special name /dev/null may be used to completely disable  this  feature. Note  that  Pinentry  will  not  create  that file, it will only change the modification and access time.
be somewhat more quiet

the default calibration time to milliseconds.  The given value is capped at 60 seconds; a value of 0 resets to  the  com‐ piled-in  default.   This option is re-read on a SIGHUP (or gpg‐ conf --reload gpg-agent) and the  S2K  count  is  then  re-cali‐ brated.

the  iteration  count  used  to protect the passphrase. This option can be used to override the auto-calibration done by default.  The auto-calibration computes a count  which  requires by  default 100ms to mangle a given passphrase.  See also --s2k- calibration.
The  default  is installation  dependent  and  can be shown with the gpgconf com‐ mand.
run in server mode (foreground)
sh-style command output
use ALGO to show ssh fingerprints

can be  used  to override this check: the new gpg-agent process will try to take over the communication sockets from the already run‐ ning process and start anyway.  This option  should  in  general not be used.

the   default  name  for  the  global  trustlist  from "trustlist.txt" to file.  If file does not contain  any  slashes and  does  not start with "~/" it is searched in the system con‐ figuration directory (‘/etc/gnupg’).
use PGM as the tpm2daemon program
These  op‐ tions  have  no  more effect.  The command gpg-agent --use-stan‐ dard-socket-p will thus always return success.
You can  increase the  verbosity  by giving several verbose commands to gpg-agent, such as ‘-vv’.

subcommands.name: for
subcommands.description: use  as different socket types (e.g. ssh, extra) as long as they are identified in the environment  variable  LISTEN_FDNAMES (see  sd_listen_fds(3)  on some Linux distributions for more in‐ formation on this convention).
